positive.review:
Best racing game out there

If you've ever played FH4/5 and caught yourself thinking "I wish I could learn real track layouts and get better at racing and not get rammed while at it", - this is a game for you.

[b]Pros[/b]:
- cars feel great
- FFB
- great with controller or a wheel
- you can adjust ABS and TC for every car on the fly, which essentially lets you adjust the difficulty
- graphics are pretty good for a simulator
- great tracks, even more if you count DLCs
- no subscriptions, no microtransactions
- safety rating system

[b]Cons[/b]:
- lack of "gamification". You can't really see yourself progress, you will have to make up challenges for yourself. There's a singleplayer (practice, hotlap and a quick race + career/championship) and unranked multiplayer. Ranked multiplayer is just a race with higher stakes.
- people online only race on Monza, Spa, Nurburgring and like 3 other tracks.
- haven't qualified for LFM yet, but as I understand it, that's a kind of community supproted crutch for lackluster native ranked online
- you can't report players in online servers
- unranked servers only have a safety rating of 50 at best (out of 99 possible)

Great game, I'm a retired iracing player and acc is just better, in just 3 days or so I got a 71 SA and its still going up. The rating system is so so much better than iracing esp with the hell on earth that is the rookie licsence. Good livery design software. My only problem is that the setup screen is too complicated and detailed which is just an issue on my side and I hope I will understand car setups better in the future. Great car handling but could be improved on the multiplayer side. But definetly a must play for simracers and GT racing enjoyers, I recommend buying while its on sale along with some dlcs.

But the game itself? Absolute top tier.

I mean, the game is freaking fantastic, no doubt about it. I popped my sim-rig cherry on this game, HOWEVER...! (Very helpful tip incoming in 3..2..1..!)
IF you have the problem of the BRAKE and THROTTLE sharing the SAME AXIS in the setup screen:
(1) Click the little arrow on the right of the THROTTLE Option to access the MENU.
(2) Select "Invert Axis"
(3) Set MINIMUM LIMIT on both BRAKE and THROTTLE to 100% (Leave the MAX limit in 0%)
(4) Done!
This should fix the shared axis problem (Makes driving nearly impossible!) I did wish it was as easy as the Assetto Corsa (Orig) Wheel Wizard, but this worked for me on an old 2-pedal Logitech Wheel.
And don't give up if you spend more time spinning off the track at the beginning - play with your TRACTION CONTROL and ABS until you get a feel for the dynamics and physics of the game.
It runs on my very old laptop with medium settings, still looks and sounds amazing!
I'll never be able to afford a PS5 for GT7, but I reckon this Racing Sim is right up there with it, so enjoy, and expect to spend a LOT of time (and fun) learning new tracks and getting the realistic feel of the cars!

The Good (What Used to Be)
Assetto Corsa Competizione had promise. Initially, it delivered a reasonably authentic GT racing experience with solid physics and decent car handling. The version 1.9 update showed the developers could still produce meaningful improvements to the simulation aspects that made the game worthwhile for serious racing enthusiasts.

The Bad (Everything Since)
Unfortunately, Kunos Simulazioni have completely bollocked what was once a respectable racing simulator. The developers made the catastrophic decision to pivot away from their core audience‚Äîactual racing enthusiasts‚Äîand instead pandered to streamers and influencers who prioritise flashy content over authentic simulation.

Major Issues:
Abandoned Development: The last meaningful update was over a year ago. For a live-service racing game, this is absolutely unacceptable
Misguided Priorities: Streamers whined about realistic tyre wear being "too hard" because they couldn't flat-out thrash the car for entire races without consequences. So the developers neutered the tyre model to let content creators produce more "exciting" footage rather than maintain authentic racing strategy
Community Neglect: Long-standing issues reported by the racing community remain unaddressed whilst developers chased mainstream appeal

The Verdict
What was once a promising GT racing simulator has become a cautionary tale about developers losing sight of their purpose. The shift towards appealing to content creators rather than racing enthusiasts has resulted in a game that satisfies neither demographic effectively.
The extended development silence suggests Kunos have either moved on entirely or are planning some sort of reboot, but given their recent track record, neither prospect inspires confidence.
Do not recommend. Save your money and stick with other racing sims that still respect their core audience. Like Le Mans Ultimate or iRacing. Assetto Corsa Competizione is a perfect example of how not to manage a racing game's development lifecycle.

Misguided Priorities: Streamers whined about realistic tyre wear being "too hard" because they couldn't flat-out thrash the car for entire races without consequences. So the developers neutered the tyre model to let content creators produce more "exciting" footage rather than maintain authentic racing strategy
Community Neglect: Long-standing issues reported by the racing community remain unaddressed whilst developers chased mainstream appeal

The Verdict
What was once a promising GT racing simulator has become a cautionary tale about developers losing sight of their purpose. The shift towards appealing to content creators rather than racing enthusiasts has resulted in a game that satisfies neither demographic effectively.
The extended development silence suggests Kunos have either moved on entirely or are planning some sort of reboot, but given their recent track record, neither prospect inspires confidence.
Do not recommend. Save your money and stick with other racing sims that still respect their core audience. Like Le Mans Ultimate or iRacing. Assetto Corsa Competizione is a perfect example of how not to manage a racing game's development lifecycle.
